```{r setup, include=FALSE}
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = TRUE)
library(dplyr)
library(rsofun)
library(ggplot2)
library(patchwork)

load("F:/rwsc/driver.Rda")
load("F:/rwsc/obs.Rda")
# load("F:/rwsc/settings.Rda")
# load("F:/rwsc/params_d.Rda")
# load("F:/rwsc/params.Rda")

source("F:/rwsc/R/cost_mae_swbm.R")

settings <- list(
  method  = "gensa",
  metric  = cost_mae_swbm,
  control = list(max.call = 1e4),  # change this to 1e4 for final calibration
  par     = list(
    exp_et  = list(lower=0.01, upper=1.5, init = 0.03),
    beta_et = list(lower=0.03,  upper=1.0, init = 0.6),
    rwsc    = list(lower=20,   upper=1000, init = 200)
    )
)

```

## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}


sitenames <- df_drivers2$sitename
obs_4 <- obs_3
Selected <- sample.int(nrow(obs_4[[2]][[13]]),floor(365*0.5*df_drivers2[13,]$params_siml[[1]]$nyeartrend))
obs_4[[2]][[13]][-Selected,]$le <- NA


pars <- calib_sofun(
    drivers = df_drivers2[13,],  
    obs = obs_4,
    settings = settings
  )
c_wkg<-tibble()
c_wkg <- tibble(
  sitename = sitenames[[13]],
  exp_et   = pars$par[[1]],
  beta_et  = pars$par[[2]],
  rwsc     = pars$par[[3]]
)
timemid <-Sys.time()
for ( i in 1:9){
obs_4 <- obs_3
Selected <- sample.int(nrow(obs_4[[2]][[13]]),floor(365*0.5*df_drivers2[13,]$params_siml[[1]]$nyeartrend))
obs_4[[2]][[13]][-Selected,]$le <- NA


pars <- calib_sofun(
    drivers = df_drivers2[13,],  
    obs = obs_4,
    settings = settings
  ) 

  c_wkg <- c_wkg |>
    add_row(sitename = sitenames[13],
            exp_et   = pars$par[[1]],
            beta_et  =pars$par[[2]],
            rwsc     =  pars$par[[3]])
}

```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
timestart<-Sys.time()
for ( i in 1:9){
obs_4 <- obs_3
Selected <- sample.int(nrow(obs_4[[2]][[13]]),floor(365*0.5*df_drivers2[13,]$params_siml[[1]]$nyeartrend))
obs_4[[2]][[13]][-Selected,]$le <- NA


pars <- calib_sofun(
    drivers = df_drivers2[13,],  
    obs = obs_4,
    settings = settings
  ) 

  c_wkg <- c_wkg |>
    add_row(sitename = sitenames[13],
            exp_et   = pars$par[[1]],
            beta_et  =pars$par[[2]],
            rwsc     =  pars$par[[3]])
}


timeend<-Sys.time()

```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.
